title: Animated GIF user icons
content:
Has this been discussed before? I was just reading a thread in the design forum a few minutes ago, and had to give up because one the the frequent poster has an animated icon under his/her name. Interestingly it was a thread about art vs. design. The Art side may say he is entitled to use animation, but the design side says doing such a thing makes it impossible to read threads where he has posted. The animation is continually pulling my eyes away from the thread, ten times a second (or so).

What do others think?
author: Don McCahill

comments.content: I HATE animated gifs. I'm completely with you, and would favor an informal moratorium on them in this forum, both as avatars (user icons) and within the threads themselves.

If you must animate, loop it like thrice and that's it.

hhp

You are all very right. And in support of your rightness I have reduced my previously infinite loop to no loop.

While we're on the topic of such annoyances, I feel the same way about signatures.
I feel the same way about all posts that I disagree with, or disagree with me.

Slow+Steady?! \> /  
Blow+Bloody?! \> x

I feel the same about all these non-conformist free thinking radicals who's user icons are any size other than the requested 60x60 pixels. You all just make the place sooo untidy. Grrrr.

If you have a problem with that you can complain to  
jon @ obsessivecompulsive.org

While I agree that animated gifs can be quite annoying, particularly if they recycle forever, I would rather put up with nausiating animated gifs than suggest further censorship of Typophile members.

ChrisL

Both animated GIFs and censorship have their place.  
The trick isn't to banish, it's to relish. Or sauerkraut, depending.

hhp

Some browsers can stop the animation. Pressing ESC will do it in Firefox. I'm told that you can hit the Stop button in Internet Exploder to do the same.

Some animations are indeed annoying, but others (such as Eric\_West's old one) are truly awe-inspiring.

s'marks

_free thinking radicals who’s user icons are any size other than the requested 60x60 pixels._

Strange bedfellows, eh Hrant?
60x60px seems awfully small, given the amound of space the dateline takes up.

Nick, you lost me. But strange, yeah, everything pretty much is. Life itself seems so surreal to me these days. I look at stuff, and I think, come on, this can't really be happening.

hhp

"60x60px seems awfully small..."

It is an icon, not a mural. Anyone can come up with a decent icon within 60 pixels. It isn't just "how much space", it is overhead on page load. I would sure rather see pages load fast than turn the icon windows into a Soho gallery space. Look at Hrant's, his is only half that size and still reads well.

ChrisL
Haha. Ok. Yes, I agree. We need to stick to the requested dimension. But, Chris, you are guilty of filling some of the threads with much more than icons. ;^)
I think most of us are guilty of this one, Tiff.... ;-)

Filled them with groans? Now I am guilty :-/  
Be careful Tiff, or I will ask Little Richard to come back :-D

ChrisL

I think it doesn't have to do with animating. It's 'how' it animates. Most animating icons draw too much attention it's true. But Nick's doesn't. I think it's just fine. I also think that Hrant probably has the single most effective icon here.

I have said it before but just for fun - my all time favorite is this one.

[http://typophile.com/user/3247](http://web.archive.org/web/20130503103646/http:/typophile.com/user/3247 "http://typophile.com/user/3247")

It takes a while, but it's worth it. Basically after a minute the moth flys away & 20 seconds later it comes back. It so low key...

Anyway, I would be opposed to a moritorium.

HAha! Yes, true. We all fill threads with hot air. P^:

I was just poking fun. No harm, no foul. :^P

As the person who suggested the voluntary moratorium I'll just say there is a difference between a subtly animated gif like Stephen's and a butterfly madly flapping its wings in the middle of a thread. It also affects how seriously I take the content, and thus the user.

nuff said.

_"It is an icon, not a mural."_

Funny you should say that Chris. I've considered making all the 60x60px Typophile user icons into a giant mosaic/quilt style graphic. Wouldn't that be nice? It could make a rather pleasing, if somewhat noisy, desktop wallpaper.

The non-conformist regulars would need resizing though, otherwise Hrant would be conspicuous by his absence.

<cite> It also affects how seriously I take the content, and thus the user. </cite>

That's probably true for me too. Even although I hope I can seperate the text from the icon the icon probably does have an impact. Especially at first.

I also had zero arguement with the Stephen's animating icon.

Pedants may insist that user icons be primarily typographic in nature. Not that I ever would of course.

But I could go along with it if required...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130503103646im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TypophileAvatarJoke_3721.jpg)

"there is a difference between a subtly animated gif like Stephen’s and a butterfly madly flapping its wings in the middle of a thread."

I fully agree, though I thought you might bring up the madly flapping mammaries of another animated gif seen here recently.

Yes: It's just a visual cue to identify the poster quickly, not ad space. They could even be smaller and still function. I also don't want to be distracted by them while reading.

Jon,  
They don't have to be type related or even look loike Crest Toothpaste. They can even be medieval vegetable broth :-)

This is a Flash-y site. How about only allowing animations on mouse over, which is of course, when it also zooms to 3x size? Even better still, details about the post author could pop out below it(a/s/l, online status, blood type, blog site, hey this could be endless) as well.~

smarks wrote:

<cite>Some browsers can stop the animation. Pressing ESC will do it in Firefox.</cite>

Firefox can also be configured to allow animated GIFs to play only once, or even to disable GIF animation altogether. See [this article](http://web.archive.org/web/20130503103646/http:/kb.mozillazine.org/Firefox_:_Tips_:_Animated_Images) for details.

I would hate to see animated GIFs categorically banned around here; when used with restraint, as in Nick Shinn's avatar, animation can be very effective. I think avatar creation can be considered an art form in itself, and animation is a useful tool in the artist's toolbox.

The dish I pictured is Greek spanokopita--spinich, feta cheese, filo pastery, and herbs. Very tasty. I never find it made as well as my Grandmother's though but I keep hoping :-)

ChrisL
I've made it a few times, but never have gotten the hang of it -- my baklava, OTOH, is pretty good....

The tough part, Linda, is keeping the pastry flaky and buttery while keeping the spinich filling moist. Most of the time, you get both dry or both soggy. Yiayia knew how to do it!

ChrisL

I had a great one in Victoria last month, as a take away, no less: the secret has to do with high heat to crisp up the base, and squeezing out the moisture from the cheese in the filling.

(And it's "spinach" the last time I looked, unless you've hybridized some new sort of veggie....) ;-)
